guids.description: Admin security component that displays unacknowledged attack alerts (bot attacks, credential stuffing, distributed attacks) with severity-coded UI and acknowledgement controls.
Type definition for an attack alert document from the attack_alerts Firestore collection.
Human-readable labels for attack type codes, used in alert card headings.
Descriptive text for each attack type, shown as secondary detail in alert cards.
Main exported component that queries unacknowledged attack alerts and renders a severity-coded summary bar with expandable detail cards.
Memoised Firestore query for unacknowledged attack alerts, gated on admin status to prevent permission errors.
Acknowledges a single attack alert by updating its Firestore document with acknowledged=true, the admin's user ID, and a timestamp.
Acknowledges all currently visible attack alerts in parallel using Promise.all.
Splits alerts into critical and warning groups to drive severity-based UI styling (pulsing red vs amber).
Renders a single attack alert card with severity-coded styling, attack details (IP, target, attempts), and an acknowledge button.
Admin component for toggling the global audit logging system on or off via admin_configuration/global Firestore document.
Type definition for the audit settings shape stored in admin_configuration/global.
Reads the current audit settings from the admin_configuration/global Firestore document, defaulting to disabled.
Writes updated audit settings to the admin_configuration/global Firestore document using merge to preserve other fields.
Main exported component providing a toggle switch and save button for enabling/disabling global audit logging.
Loads the current audit settings from Firestore on component mount.
Persists the current audit logging toggle state to Firestore and shows a success/failure toast.
Updates the local settings state when the toggle switch is changed, without persisting until save.
Admin component for viewing the system audit log of user activity and system events.
Type definition for an audit log document from the audit_logs Firestore collection.
Props interface for AuditLogViewer, accepting pre-fetched user data to resolve user IDs to display names.
Main exported component that displays the last 100 audit log entries with user resolution, action badges, and expandable details.
Memoised Firestore query that fetches the 100 most recent audit logs ordered by timestamp descending.
Maps audit log action types to Badge variants for consistent visual styling.
Resolves a userId to a User object from the pre-fetched allUsers list for display name lookup.

Admin component for running data integrity checks across all Firestore collections and displaying results. Validates users, drivers, races, predictions, team coverage, race results, scores, standings, and leagues.
TypeScript interface for the component props: receives the preloaded allUsers array and loading flag from the parent admin page.
Type alias for the sequential check phases, used to track progress through the validation pipeline.
Human-readable labels for each check phase, displayed above the progress bar during a check run.
Progress percentage for each check phase, used to fill the progress bar proportionally.
Render a small status icon (green check, yellow warning, red X) based on a check result status.
Render a coloured Badge (Pass/Warning/Error) based on a check result status.
Render a coloured Badge (Warning/Error) based on an individual issue severity level.

Main Consistency Checker component. Orchestrates on-demand data fetching, sequential validation checks across 9 categories, progress display, summary table, score type breakdown, issue details, and export to error_logs.

Execute the full consistency check pipeline: users, drivers, races, predictions, team coverage, race results, scores, standings, and leagues. Fetches Firestore data on-demand per phase to minimise memory usage.
Export all detected issues to the error_logs Firestore collection with a correlation ID for tracking.
Derived count of total issues across all check categories, used to control UI visibility of the Issues Detail card and Export button.
Admin component for managing the email queue (push, resend, delete) and viewing historical email send logs.
Type definition for a historical email log document from the email_logs Firestore collection.
Type definition for a queued email document from the email_queue collection, including retry state.
Main exported component providing email queue management (push/resend/delete) and historical email log viewing.
Fetches all queued emails (including failed) from the /api/email-queue endpoint.
Triggers the initial fetch of queued emails when the admin user is confirmed.
Sends a single queued email immediately via the /api/email-queue push action.
Re-queues a single failed email for another round of retry attempts.
Deletes a single queued email from the queue, discarding it permanently.
Pushes all pending queued emails for immediate sending in a single batch operation.
Re-queues all failed emails for another round of retry attempts in a single batch operation.
Deletes all emails from the queue, clearing it entirely.
Memoised Firestore query for historical email send logs ordered by timestamp descending.
Maps an email log status to a Badge variant for consistent visual status representation.
Renders a status badge for a queued email, showing failed state, retry count, or pending.
Computes counts of pending and failed emails for display in the header and button labels.
Admin component for viewing, searching, filtering, and resolving system error logs.
Type definition for an error log document from the error_logs Firestore collection.
Sanitizes stack traces to remove absolute paths and sensitive information before display. Prevents information disclosure of server directory structure and file paths.
Maps PX error code prefixes to display colours and labels for visual categorisation.
Configuration arrays for the two rows of filter tabs: category filters and view mode filters.
Extracts the PX category prefix from an error code string, falling back to PX-9 (Unknown).
Small utility component that copies text to the clipboard with visual feedback.
Main exported component that provides a full error log viewing interface with filtering, searching, grouping, and resolution tracking.
Memoised Firestore query that fetches the 500 most recent error logs ordered by timestamp descending.
Applies category, search term, time-based, and resolution status filters to the raw error logs.
Extracts the error code from a log, checking multiple possible locations in the log structure.
Groups filtered logs by their error code for the "Grouped" view mode.
Computes aggregate statistics (total count and per-category counts) across all unfiltered error logs.
Toggles the expanded/collapsed state of a group in the grouped view.
Renders a single error log entry with expandable details, copy-able correlation ID, stack trace, context, and a "Mark as Resolved" action.
Marks an error log as resolved by updating the Firestore document with resolved=true and a timestamp.
Safely extracts a Date object from the log's timestamp, handling both Firestore seconds and ISO string formats.
Safely serialises the error log's context object to a JSON string for display.
Admin component for reviewing and managing user-submitted bug reports and feature requests, with filtering, status updates, and deletion.
Type definition for a feedback item document in the Firestore feedback collection. Includes optional referenceId field (BG-001/FB-001).
Maps feedback status values to Tailwind CSS colour classes for badge styling.
Main FeedbackManager component providing a filterable, expandable list of feedback items with status management and deletion.
Local state for feedback items, loading flag, and filter selections (type and status).
Sets up a real-time Firestore listener on the feedback collection, ordered by creation date descending.
Updates a feedback item's status in Firestore. When resolving, stamps the current app version and resolution timestamp.
Permanently deletes a feedback item from the Firestore feedback collection.
Formats a Firestore Timestamp into a human-readable UK-locale date string with time.
Filters the feedback array by the currently selected type and status filters.
Computes summary statistics (bug count, feature count, new count) for the stats cards display.
Renders a loading skeleton while feedback data is being fetched from Firestore.
Renders the complete Feedback Manager UI: stats cards, type/status filter buttons, and an expandable accordion list of feedback items with reference ID badges.
Admin component for managing the Hot News feed: toggle AI updates, manually edit content, refresh via AI, and optionally email subscribers.
Main HotNewsManager component providing AI toggle, content editor, refresh button, and email dispatch controls.
Local state managing the hot news settings, loading/error states, form fields, and operation flags.
Fetches the current hot news settings from Firestore on component mount and populates local state.
Saves manual content edits and the AI toggle to Firestore, logs an audit event, and optionally sends emails to all subscribers.
Conditionally sends hot news content via email to all subscribed users after a successful save.

Triggers the AI-powered hot news generation flow, updates the textarea content, and persists the result to Firestore. Detects stale Server Action hash (post-deployment cache mismatch) and prompts user to refresh.
Renders a loading skeleton while hot news settings are being fetched from Firestore.
Renders an error alert when the initial settings fetch fails, blocking access to the editor.
Renders the full Hot News management UI: AI toggle, content textarea, email checkbox, save and refresh buttons.
Admin component for viewing all leagues, their owners, member counts, invite codes, and expandable member lists.
Defines the props contract for LeaguesManager, requiring the full user list and its loading state for team name resolution.
Main LeaguesManager component rendering a table of all leagues with expandable member details and invite code copy functionality.
Memoised Firestore query for the entire leagues collection, used by the useCollection hook.
Creates a Map from user ID to team name for efficient lookup when resolving league member and owner names.
Resolves a user ID to a human-readable team name, with special handling for the system owner.
Copies a league's invite code to the system clipboard and shows a confirmation toast.
Toggles the expanded/collapsed state for a league row to show or hide member details.
Renders the leagues table with columns for name, owner, member count, invite code, and an expand/collapse control.
Admin component for monitoring online user sessions and managing Single User Mode (purge all sessions, restrict access to one admin).
Defines the session timeout window; sessions inactive beyond this threshold are considered expired.
Type definition for a Firestore presence document, tracking a user's online status and session GUIDs.
Defines the props contract for OnlineUsersManager, requiring the full user list and its loading state.
Type definition for Single User Mode configuration stored in admin_configuration/global.
Fire-and-forget helper to log errors to the error_logs Firestore collection with full context.
Main OnlineUsersManager component displaying active sessions in a table and providing Single User Mode controls.
Fetches the current Single User Mode configuration from admin_configuration/global on component mount.
Activates Single User Mode: purges all presence sessions except the current admin's, then sets the flag in admin_configuration.
Deactivates Single User Mode: clears the flag in admin_configuration/global so all users can connect normally.
Memoised Firestore query for the entire presence collection, used by the useCollection hook.
Derives the list of users with active sessions by joining presence data with user details, filtering by session timeout.
Computes the total count of active sessions across all users, only counting sessions within the timeout window.
Resolves the team name of the admin who activated Single User Mode for display in the warning banner.
Renders the complete Online Users UI: session table, Single User Mode controls, and status banner.
Admin component for entering official F1 race results and managing existing results. Provides a two-step wizard: race selection then driver picker for top-6 positions.
Normalize a raceId string by stripping GP/Sprint suffixes and replacing spaces with hyphens for consistent matching against prediction raceId format.
Convert a driver ID (e.g., "hamilton") to a 3-letter display code (e.g., "HAM") by looking up the driver in F1Drivers static data.
TypeScript interface for a race result document stored in the race_results Firestore collection.
Type alias for the two-step wizard flow: race selection then result entry.
Main admin component for entering and managing official F1 race results via a two-step wizard (select race, then pick top-6 drivers).
State management for the two-step wizard flow, driver selections, submission status, and deletion tracking.
Fetch the count of unique team predictions when a race is selected, to show how many teams will be scored. Counts ALL predictions (carry-forward model).
Memoised Firestore query for fetching all existing race results, ordered by submission date descending.
Derived list of F1 drivers not yet placed in any of the 6 result positions, available for selection.
Add a driver to the first empty position slot in the predictions array.
Remove a driver from a specific position slot, making them available again.
Swap a driver with the adjacent position (up or down) to reorder the result.
Transition from step 1 (race selection) to step 2 (driver entry) after validating a race is selected.
Navigate back to step 1 (race selection) and reset the driver selections.
Validate all 6 positions are filled and open the confirmation dialog before submitting results.
Generate a compact text summary of the result (e.g., "1-HAM, 2-VER, 3-NOR, ...") for the confirmation dialog.
Submit the confirmed race results to the server-side /api/calculate-scores endpoint for secure score calculation, then trigger email notifications via /api/send-results-email.
Delete a race result and its associated scores via the server-side /api/delete-scores endpoint.
Format a Firestore Timestamp or Date to a human-readable en-GB string (DD Mon YYYY, HH:MM).
Read-only admin component displaying the fixed scoring rules for the Prix Six fantasy league, sourced from SCORING_POINTS and SCORING_DERIVED constants.
Main ScoringManager component rendering a card that explains each scoring tier and the maximum possible score.
Admin component for toggling global site functions: user login and new user sign-up. Reads and writes admin_configuration/global in Firestore.
Type definition for the global site settings stored in admin_configuration/global.
Main SiteFunctionsManager component providing toggle switches for global site features with save persistence.
Fetches the current global site settings from Firestore on component mount.
Persists the current toggle states to Firestore and logs an audit event for the change.
Renders a loading skeleton while settings are being fetched from Firestore.
Renders the site functions card with toggle switches for login and sign-up, plus a save button.
Read-only admin component displaying standing data: F1 drivers grouped by team and the full race calendar schedule.
Groups the flat F1Drivers array into a lookup keyed by team name for team-based rendering.
Maps F1 constructor names to Tailwind CSS background colour classes for visual team badges.
Main StandingDataManager component rendering two cards: F1 Drivers by team and the Race Calendar table.
Formats an ISO date string into a human-readable UK-locale date (e.g., "Sat, 15 Mar 2026").
Formats an ISO date string into a human-readable UK-locale time with timezone (e.g., "14:00 GMT").
Determines if a race has already occurred by comparing its time to the current date.
Renders the complete standing data view: driver cards grouped by team and a race calendar table.
Admin component for managing user teams: view, edit, delete, toggle admin status, and unlock locked accounts.
Defines the props contract for TeamManager, requiring the full user list and its loading state.
Main TeamManager component that renders a table of all users with edit, admin toggle, and delete actions.
Local state for the edit dialog: tracks which user is selected and what editable fields contain.
Opens the edit dialog and pre-populates form fields with the selected user's current data.
Persists edited user fields (teamName, email, isAdmin) to Firestore and closes the dialog.
Toggles a user's admin status between admin and regular user.
Permanently deletes a user and all their data from the system.
Resets a locked user's badLoginAttempts counter to zero, unlocking their account.
Renders the team management UI: a table of users with action buttons and an edit dialog.
Admin component for managing WhatsApp integration: worker status monitoring, alert configuration, custom message sending, message queue viewing, and alert history.
Dynamically import QRCode component to avoid SSR issues; includes fallback UI on load failure.
Constants for the WhatsApp proxy API endpoint and message length limit.
TypeScript interface for the WhatsApp worker status response, including connection state, groups, and keep-alive health.
TypeScript interface for entries in the whatsapp_status_log Firestore collection, tracking connection state changes.
TypeScript interface for messages in the whatsapp_queue Firestore collection, representing messages to be sent by the worker.
Static configuration defining all alert categories and their individual alert types for the Alert Control Panel UI.

Main admin component for WhatsApp integration management. Provides worker status monitoring, QR code authentication, alert settings configuration, custom message sending, message queue display, and alert history.
State management for all component concerns: worker status, alert settings, message form, queue, history, status log, and QR code lifecycle.
Retrieve Firebase auth token for authenticated API requests to the WhatsApp proxy.
Fetch QR code string from the WhatsApp worker via the proxy API for display in the QR scanner UI.
Fetch current worker status (connection, groups, keep-alive) from the WhatsApp proxy API. Auto-selects first matching group.
Fetch WhatsApp alert settings from Firestore and populate local editing state with saved values.
Poll worker status on mount and every 30 seconds to keep the status card up to date.
Auto-refresh the QR code every 30 seconds while the worker is awaiting QR scan and a QR code is displayed.
Track QR code age in seconds to display freshness warnings and auto-expire visual feedback.
Fetch alert settings from Firestore on component mount.
Real-time Firestore listener for the last 10 messages in whatsapp_queue, ordered by creation time descending.
Real-time Firestore listener for the last 50 entries in whatsapp_alert_history, ordered by creation time descending.
Real-time Firestore listener for the last 25 entries in whatsapp_status_log, ordered by timestamp descending.
Persist alert settings (master switch, test mode, target group, alert toggles) to Firestore and log the change in audit trail.
Queue a custom message for delivery to a WhatsApp group via the worker. Adds to whatsapp_queue and whatsapp_alert_history, and logs an audit event.
Toggle an individual alert type on or off in the local editing state.
Render a coloured Badge component based on message queue status (PENDING, PROCESSING, SENT, FAILED).
Format a Firestore Timestamp to a human-readable en-GB date/time string (DD/MM HH:MM).
Derived boolean that compares local editing state against last-saved settings to detect unsaved changes.

API route that allows an authenticated user to create a secondary team for the fantasy league. Enforces uniqueness, applies late-joiner handicap if the season has started, and registers the team in the global league.
Defines the shape of the incoming secondary team creation request, containing only the desired team name.

Main POST handler that authenticates the user, validates the team name, checks for duplicates, creates the secondary team record, registers it in the global league, applies a late-joiner handicap if applicable, and logs audit events.
Authenticates the request by extracting and verifying the Firebase Auth bearer token from the Authorization header.
Parses the request body and validates that the team name meets the minimum length requirement (3 characters).
Checks that the user exists and does not already have a secondary team. Prevents duplicate secondary team creation.
Case-insensitive uniqueness check across all existing primary and secondary team names to prevent duplicate team names in the league.
Writes the secondary team name to the user document and adds the secondary team ID to the global league's member list.

Late-joiner handicap: if the season has already started (scores exist), the new secondary team starts 5 points behind the last-place team. This prevents new teams from having an unfair advantage by joining with zero points mid-season.
Logs the successful secondary team creation in the audit trail and returns a success response with the new team name and ID.

Top-level error handler that catches any unhandled exception during secondary team creation, logs it with a correlation ID, and returns a 500 response with the correlation ID for user-reportable error tracing.
Admin API route for deleting a user account  coordinates removal from Firebase Auth, Firestore users/presence collections, and league memberships with full audit logging.
Zod schema for validating delete request  ensures both userId and adminUid are present and non-empty.
POST handler that orchestrates user deletion: validates input, checks admin permissions, prevents self-deletion, removes Auth + Firestore records, cleans up league memberships, and logs audit events.
Early return on Zod validation failure  provides field-level errors to the caller.
Verify the requesting user has admin privileges before allowing deletion.
Safety guard  prevent admins from accidentally deleting their own account.
Capture user data before deletion for inclusion in the audit log.
Delete user from Firebase Auth. If user is already missing from Auth (orphaned Firestore record), proceed with Firestore cleanup only.
Delete Firestore user and presence documents in a batch. Logs a critical error if Auth was already deleted but Firestore cleanup fails (split-brain state).
Remove the deleted user's ID from all league memberUserIds arrays. Best-effort  failure is logged but does not block the response.
Write an audit log entry recording who deleted whom and the deleted user's details.
Top-level error handler  catches any unhandled exceptions, logs to error_logs, and returns a safe 500 response with correlation ID.

Module-level file header for fetch-timing-data route. Declares OPENF1_BASE, OPENF1_TOKEN_URL, FETCH_TIMEOUT_MS (10s), and the in-memory OAuth2 token cache. gill 2026-02-19: added FETCH_TIMEOUT_MS constant and fetchWithTimeout/safeParseJson helpers to fix indefinite-hang and non-JSON-response bugs.
Zod schema validating the POST request body  requires sessionKey (positive integer) only. adminUid was removed in a prior security fix; gill 2026-02-19 updated description to reflect this.
Format a lap duration in seconds to "M:SS.mmm" display string.

POST handler orchestrating the full OpenF1 fetch pipeline. gill 2026-02-19: all fetch() calls replaced with fetchWithTimeout() (10s timeout); all .json() calls replaced with safeParseJson(); per-step try/catch for timeouts returns 504 instead of unhandled exception; verbose console logging added throughout.
Verify the requesting user has isAdmin=true in Firestore before allowing the fetch. Uses authenticated UID from token (not request body). gill 2026-02-19: added verbose logging.

Acquire OpenF1 token then fetch session metadata for the given sessionKey. gill 2026-02-19: fetch() replaced with fetchWithTimeout() (returns 504 on abort); .json() replaced with safeParseJson(); AbortError caught and returned as distinct 504 vs 502.

Fetch meeting metadata (name, location, circuit, country) for the session's meetingKey. gill 2026-02-19: fetch() replaced with fetchWithTimeout(); .json() replaced with safeParseJson(); timeout/network error returns 504.
Fetch all drivers who participated in the session. gill 2026-02-19: fetch() replaced with fetchWithTimeout(); .json() replaced with safeParseJson(); timeout/network error returns 504.
Deduplicate drivers by driver_number, keeping first occurrence. gill 2026-02-19: added verbose log of unique driver count after deduplication.

Fetch lap data for each driver in parallel (Promise.all), compute best valid lap. gill 2026-02-19: fetch() replaced with fetchWithTimeout() per-driver; .json() replaced with inline text()+JSON.parse() guard; individual driver timeout/parse failures return null (graceful) instead of propagating.
Write computed timing data to Firestore app-settings/pub-chat-timing using .set() to fully overwrite. gill 2026-02-19: added verbose logging before and after write.
Write audit log entry to audit_logs recording the admin timing fetch. gill 2026-02-19: added verbose log confirmation after write.

Top-level catch block  catches any unhandled exception, logs traced error to error_logs, returns safe 500. gill 2026-02-19: nested try/catch added so a Firebase Admin failure during logging does not cause a second uncaught exception; fallback minimal response added.

OpenF1 OAuth2 token acquisition with 55-minute module-level cache. Returns null if credentials are absent or the token endpoint fails. gill 2026-02-19: fetch() replaced with fetchWithTimeout(); token response parsed via safeParseJson(); added guard for missing access_token field; verbose logging added.

fetchWithTimeout() helper  wraps native fetch() with an AbortController timeout. After FETCH_TIMEOUT_MS (10s) the request is aborted, causing fetch() to throw a DOMException named AbortError. Callers catch this and return HTTP 504. gill 2026-02-19: new function added to fix indefinite-hang bug.

safeParseJson() helper  reads response body as text then calls JSON.parse(). If parsing fails (e.g. OpenF1 returned an HTML error page), throws a descriptive Error including the HTTP status and a 300-char body preview. Replaces direct .json() calls to prevent SyntaxError propagating to top-level catch. gill 2026-02-19: new function added to fix non-JSON-response bug.

Module-level file header for openf1-sessions proxy route. Declares OPENF1_BASE, OPENF1_TOKEN_URL, FETCH_TIMEOUT_MS (10s), and independent module-level OAuth2 token cache. gill 2026-02-19: added FETCH_TIMEOUT_MS and fetchWithTimeout/safeParseJson helpers; documented that token cache is independent of fetch-timing-data route.

GET handler proxying OpenF1 meetings (?year=) or sessions (?meetingKey=) for admin UI dropdowns. gill 2026-02-19: all fetch() replaced with fetchWithTimeout(); all .json() replaced with safeParseJson(); timeout returns 504 with clear message; verbose logging added throughout.

Fetch and return meetings for a given year from OpenF1 (?year= branch). gill 2026-02-19: fetch() replaced with fetchWithTimeout(); .json() replaced with safeParseJson(); timeout/network errors return 504.

Fetch and return sessions for a given meeting from OpenF1 (?meetingKey= branch). gill 2026-02-19: fetch() replaced with fetchWithTimeout(); .json() replaced with safeParseJson(); timeout/network errors return 504.

Top-level catch block  logs traced error to error_logs and returns safe 500. gill 2026-02-19: nested try/catch added so Firebase Admin failure during logging does not cause second uncaught exception; fallback minimal response added.

OpenF1 OAuth2 token acquisition with 55-minute module-level cache for openf1-sessions route. Independent of the cache in fetch-timing-data route. gill 2026-02-19: fetch() replaced with fetchWithTimeout(); token response parsed via safeParseJson(); added guard for missing access_token; verbose logging added.

fetchWithTimeout() helper for openf1-sessions route  wraps native fetch() with AbortController timeout. After FETCH_TIMEOUT_MS (10s) the request is aborted, throwing AbortError. Callers catch this and return HTTP 504. gill 2026-02-19: new function added to fix indefinite-hang bug.

safeParseJson() helper for openf1-sessions route  reads response body as text then calls JSON.parse(). Throws descriptive Error with HTTP status and 300-char body preview if parsing fails. Prevents SyntaxError from non-JSON responses propagating to top-level catch. gill 2026-02-19: new function added to fix non-JSON-response bug.
Admin API route for updating user profile fields (email, teamName, isAdmin, mustChangePin) with full validation, deduplication, and downstream propagation.
Zod schema for strict request validation  prevents mass assignment by only allowing known fields.

POST handler that orchestrates admin user updates: validates input, checks admin permissions, deduplicates email/teamName, updates Auth + Firestore, propagates teamName to predictions, and logs audit events.
Early return on Zod validation failure  provides detailed field-level errors to the caller.
Verify the requesting user has admin privileges before allowing any modifications.
Handle email change: normalise to lowercase, check for duplicates in both Firestore and Firebase Auth, then update Auth record.
Handle teamName change: check for case-insensitive duplicates across all users, capture old name for downstream propagation.
Persist the validated changes to the Firestore users document with a server timestamp.
Propagate teamName changes to all of the user's prediction documents (Golden Rule #3: Single Source of Truth  denormalised teamName must stay in sync).
Write a general audit log entry for every admin user update, regardless of which fields changed.
Top-level error handler  catches any unhandled exceptions, logs to error_logs, and returns a safe 500 response with correlation ID.
Admin API route for activating/deactivating Single User Mode. Verifies Firebase Auth token and server-side admin status before executing presence purge or flag operations.
Zod schema for strict request body validation  only activate/deactivate actions are permitted.
POST handler  validates token, verifies admin, executes activate or deactivate.
Token verification block  returns 401 if Authorization header is missing or invalid.
UID mismatch guard  returns 403 if token UID doesn't match body adminUid (IDOR prevention).
Server-side admin verification  returns 403 if caller does not have isAdmin=true in Firestore.

AI-powered race prediction analysis API route. Accepts a user's top-6 driver prediction and analysis weight configuration, builds a dynamic weighted prompt, calls Genkit/Gemini AI, and returns structured analysis text covering multiple F1 analysis facets and optional pundit personas.
TypeScript interface for a single driver in the user's prediction  position, driver code, full name, and constructor team.

TypeScript interface for analysis weight sliders  each facet (0-10) controls how much emphasis the AI gives to that analysis dimension. Includes two pundit personas (jackSparrow, rowanHornblower) with extended word budgets.
TypeScript interface for the full analysis request payload  race metadata, driver predictions, weight configuration, and pre-calculated total weight.
Constants defining word budgets per facet type  standard facets get 50 words each, pundit personas get up to 250 words scaled by weight.
Calculate per-facet word budgets based on weights. Standard facets get a fixed 50 words if active; pundit facets scale linearly from 0-250 words based on weight (0-10).

Build the complete AI prompt dynamically based on race details, user predictions, and weight configuration. Includes facet descriptions with emphasis levels, word budgets, exclusion notes, and formatting rules (British English, headings, verdict).

POST handler that validates weights, builds the prediction list and weighted prompt, calls Genkit AI (Gemini), and returns the analysis text. Includes dedicated error handling for AI generation failures separate from general errors.
Validate that the total weight across all facets does not exceed the maximum of 77. Prevents abuse and ensures balanced analysis.
Call Genkit AI (Gemini) with the weighted prompt and configured generation parameters. Dedicated try/catch provides specific AI error handling with detailed logging.
Top-level error handler  catches any unhandled exceptions outside of the AI call (e.g., JSON parse, validation). Logs to error_logs and returns a safe 500 response with a fallback analysis message.

Server-side API route that completes the profile for new OAuth users. Mirrors the signup route but skips Firebase Auth user creation (OAuth already created it). Validates the user exists in Auth with an OAuth provider, creates Firestore documents, enrols in global league, applies late-joiner handicap, and sends welcome email. Updates the global league memberUserIds array. Triggers welcome email.
Type contract for the expected JSON body.

Main POST handler. Validates the OAuth user in Firebase Auth, checks team name uniqueness, creates Firestore user and presence documents, handles late-joiner handicap, global league enrolment, and welcome email. the client-side onAuthStateChanged picks up the new doc and sets user state.
Validate required fields.
Validate team name length.
Verify the Firebase Auth user exists and has an OAuth provider.
Ensure no Firestore user doc exists yet (prevents double-creation).
Check for duplicate team names (case-insensitive) across both primary and secondary team names.
Check if signups are enabled.
Create the Firestore user document and presence document.
Add the new user to the global league.
Apply late-joiner handicap if the season has already started.
Send welcome email (fire-and-forget).
Log the successful OAuth registration.
Top-level error handler for unhandled exceptions.

Server-side API route that authenticates users via email + 6-digit PIN, enforces account lockout after repeated failures, logs all attempts for attack detection, and returns a Firebase custom token on success.
Extract the real client IP address from incoming requests, accounting for various proxy/CDN header conventions.
Define the brute-force protection thresholds: max allowed failed attempts and lockout window duration.
Type contract for the expected JSON body of the login request.
Main login POST handler. Validates input, checks lockout status, verifies credentials via Firebase Auth REST API, tracks failed/successful attempts, and returns a custom token on success.
Validate that both email and PIN are present before proceeding with authentication.
Look up the user document in Firestore by normalised email to check lockout status and track login attempts.

Enforce account lockout: if the user has exceeded MAX_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS within the LOCKOUT_DURATION_MS window, reject the login and log the blocked attempt. Also auto-reset the counter once the lockout window expires.
Look up the user in Firebase Auth by email to confirm the account exists in the auth system, separate from Firestore.
Verify the user's PIN (password) by calling the Firebase Auth REST API (Identity Toolkit signInWithPassword endpoint), since the Admin SDK does not support password verification directly.
Handle failed credential verification: increment the bad login attempts counter, log the failure for attack detection, write an audit record, and trigger lockout if the threshold is reached.
Handle successful authentication: generate a Firebase custom token, reset the bad login attempts counter, log the success for analytics and auditing, and return the token to the client.
Top-level catch-all error handler for any unhandled exception during login. Logs the error with full context (excluding the PIN) and returns a generic 500 response with the correlation ID.
Record a logon event in user_logons for session tracking after successful PIN authentication. Includes IP and user agent. Non-blocking  login succeeds even if tracking fails.

PX-6004.recovery: Non-blocking  login succeeds even if tracking fails. Session will expire via scheduled function.

guids.description: POST endpoint that records a user logon event in the user_logons collection for session tracking. Verifies Bearer token, accepts loginMethod, writes via Admin SDK, returns logonId.

PX-6004.recovery: Non-blocking  OAuth login continues even if logon recording fails.

guids.description: POST endpoint that records a user logout event by updating the user_logons document with logout timestamp and Logged Out status. Validates document ownership to prevent cross-user spoofing.

PX-6005.recovery: Non-blocking  logout proceeds. Session will expire via scheduled function after 24h.

guids.description: Server-side API route that handles PIN reset requests: validates the email, generates a new random 6-digit PIN, updates Firebase Auth, marks the user as mustChangePin, queues a reset email, and logs the action. Returns a generic success message regardless of whether the email exists to prevent enumeration attacks.
Type contract for the expected JSON body of the PIN reset request.

Main PIN reset POST handler. Validates the email, looks up the user in Firestore, generates a cryptographically random 6-digit PIN, updates Firebase Auth, flags the user for mandatory PIN change, queues a reset email, and writes audit records. Returns a deliberately ambiguous success message to prevent email enumeration.
Validate that the email field is present in the request body.
Look up the user in Firestore by normalised email. If no user is found, return a generic success message to prevent email enumeration attacks (attacker cannot determine which emails have accounts).
Generate a cryptographically secure random 6-digit PIN and update the user's password in Firebase Auth. Uses crypto.randomInt for uniform distribution across the 100000-999999 range.
Set the mustChangePin flag on the user's Firestore document so the application forces a PIN change on the user's next successful login.
Queue the PIN reset email by writing to the mail collection (consumed by the email sending service) and log the email to the email_logs collection for auditing and debugging.
Write an audit log entry recording that a PIN reset email was queued for this user, then return the generic success message.

Top-level catch-all error handler for any unhandled exception during PIN reset. Logs the error to error_logs (with fallback to console if logging itself fails) and returns a generic 500 response with correlation ID for support tracing.

Server-side API route that registers new users: validates input, creates Firebase Auth and Firestore records, enrols the user in the global league, applies late-joiner handicap scoring if the season has started, sends welcome and verification emails, and returns a custom token for immediate sign-in.
List of commonly guessable 6-digit PINs that are rejected during signup to enforce minimum credential strength.
Constant for the global league document ID, used to add every new user to the shared league.
Type contract for the expected JSON body of the signup request.

Main signup POST handler. Validates all input fields (email, team name, PIN strength), checks admin toggle for signup availability, prevents duplicate emails and team names, creates the Firebase Auth user and Firestore documents, handles late-joiner handicap, sends emails, and returns a custom token.
Validate that all required fields (email, team name, PIN) are present.
Validate PIN format (exactly 6 digits) and reject weak/guessable PINs from the WEAK_PINS list.
Validate that the team name is at least 3 characters long.
Check the admin_configuration/site_settings document to determine if new user signups are currently enabled. Allows admins to disable registration without code changes.
Check for duplicate email addresses in the Firestore users collection to prevent multiple accounts with the same email.
Check for duplicate team names (case-insensitive) across all existing users to ensure team name uniqueness.
Create the Firebase Auth user record with the provided email and PIN as password. Handles the auth/email-already-exists error case separately from other auth errors.
Create the Firestore user document and presence document for the newly registered user. The user document stores profile and state data; the presence document tracks online status.
Add the new user to the global league by appending their uid to the memberUserIds array. Fails silently if the global league document does not exist (non-blocking).

Apply the late-joiner handicap rule: if the season has already started (scores exist), calculate a starting score of (lowest real score - 5) so the new user starts 5 points behind last place. Skips existing adjustment scores when determining the minimum.
Send a welcome email and a verification email to the new user via internal API endpoints. Both are fire-and-forget; failures are logged but do not block signup completion.
Log the successful registration to the audit_logs collection and generate a Firebase custom token so the client can sign in immediately without a second round-trip.
Top-level catch-all error handler for any unhandled exception during signup. Logs the error to error_logs and returns a generic 500 response with correlation ID for support tracing.
API route that calculates race scores for all teams based on submitted race results and team predictions. Core scoring engine for the Prix Six fantasy league.
Defines the shape of the incoming race result submission from the admin.
Represents a single team's score result for the API response.
Represents a ranked entry in the overall standings returned by the API.
Normalises a raceId/raceName by stripping GP/Sprint suffixes and collapsing whitespace to hyphens, so predictions filed under the base race name can be matched.
Creates a Firestore document ID for race results that preserves GP vs Sprint distinction (e.g. "australia-gp" or "australia-sprint").

Main POST handler that orchestrates the entire scoring pipeline: auth check, admin verification, prediction resolution (including carry-forwards), score calculation, batch write of scores/results/audit, and standings aggregation.
Authenticates the request by verifying the Firebase Auth bearer token and confirms the user has admin privileges.
Parses and validates the race result request body, ensuring all six driver positions are provided.
Loads all users to build lookup maps from userId/teamId to team names, including secondary teams, for score attribution.
Fetches all predictions across all users via a collectionGroup query, then organises them by team and race to support the carry-forward resolution logic.
Builds a nested map (teamId -> raceId -> prediction) from all prediction documents, keeping only the latest prediction per team per race. Handles both primary and secondary team predictions.

Resolves each team's effective prediction for the current race by checking for a race-specific prediction first, then falling back to the most recent prediction from any earlier race (carry-forward rule).
Converts the latestPredictions map into a snapshot-like iterable format to maintain compatibility with the downstream scoring loop which was originally written against Firestore query snapshots.

Core scoring loop: iterates over each team's prediction, calculates points per driver using the hybrid position-based scoring system (calculateDriverPoints), applies the all-6 bonus, and prepares batch writes for score documents.
Creates synthetic prediction documents in Firestore for teams whose predictions were carried forward, ensuring the results page can find a prediction document for every scored team on every race.
Writes the official race result document to the race_results collection, storing the top-6 finishing order. Also creates an audit log entry for the result submission.
Aggregates all scores across all races to produce updated overall league standings with tie-aware ranking, returned in the API response.
Top-level error handler that catches any unhandled exception during scoring, logs it with a correlation ID, and returns a 500 response with the correlation ID for user-reportable error tracing.
API route that deletes all scores and the race result document for a given race. Used by admins to undo/re-do scoring.
Defines the shape of the incoming delete request, requiring the race identifier and optional display name.
Normalises a raceId by stripping GP/Sprint suffixes, collapsing whitespace to hyphens, and lowercasing to match the format used when scores are stored.
Main POST handler that authenticates the admin, queries all score documents for the specified race, batch-deletes them along with the race result document, and logs an audit event.
Authenticates the request by verifying the Firebase Auth bearer token and confirms the user has admin privileges before allowing score deletion.
Parses the request body and validates that a raceId is provided, then normalises it to match the stored score format.
Queries all score documents matching the normalised raceId, deletes them in a batch along with the race result document, and writes an audit log entry -- all committed atomically.
Top-level error handler that catches any unhandled exception during score deletion, logs it with a correlation ID, and returns a 500 response.
API route that provides an email system health check for admins. Checks Graph API credentials, Firebase Admin connectivity, recent email success/failure rates, and email queue depth.
Type definition for the health check response  structured result with overall status and individual check statuses for Graph credentials, Firebase Admin, recent emails, and queued emails.

GET handler  authenticates the caller via Bearer token, checks admin status, then assembles a health report by inspecting Graph API env vars, querying email_logs for failures in the last 24 hours, and checking email_queue for pending items. Returns overall status as healthy/degraded/unhealthy.

API route that manages the email queue  supports fetching queued/failed emails (GET), sending or re-queuing emails with retry logic (POST), and deleting queued emails (DELETE). Central to the email delivery reliability system.
Retry configuration constants  limits retry attempts to 3 and spaces retries 5 minutes apart to avoid hammering the Graph API during transient failures.
Type definition for a queued email document  represents an email in the email_queue Firestore collection with its delivery status, retry metadata, and content.

GET handler  fetches queued emails from Firestore. In admin mode (includeAll=true), returns up to 100 emails regardless of status. In normal mode, returns only pending emails whose nextRetryAt has passed (ready to process).

POST handler  processes email queue actions. "resend" action re-queues failed emails by resetting their retry count and status to pending. "push" action sends pending emails via Graph API, recording successes in email_daily_stats and handling failures with exponential retry logic via handleEmailFailure.

Handles email send failures with retry logic. If the retry count is below MAX_RETRY_ATTEMPTS (3), schedules a retry after RETRY_DELAY_MINUTES (5 min) by updating the queue document. If max retries are exhausted, marks the email as permanently failed.
DELETE handler  removes queued emails from Firestore. If specific emailIds are provided, deletes those; otherwise deletes all pending emails. Used by admins to clear the queue.
API route for receiving and persisting client-side errors to Firestore. Provides a server endpoint so browser-based error handlers can log errors with correlation IDs to the error_logs collection.
Initialise Firebase Admin SDK if not already done. Supports both production (Application Default Credentials) and local development (service account file).
TypeScript interface defining the expected shape of client error payloads. Ensures type safety for the request body.

POST handler that validates the incoming client error payload and writes it to the Firestore error_logs collection. Designed to be resilient  never returns an error that would worsen the client's already-errored state.
Basic validation  ensures the minimum required fields (correlationId and error message) are present.
Persist the client error to Firestore error_logs collection with full context, defaulting errorCode to PX-9001 (unknown) if not provided.

PX-9001.recovery: Check server logs with the correlation ID for root cause.

guids.description: Catch-all error handler  logs to console but returns a simple 500. Intentionally does NOT call logError() to avoid recursive error logging. The client is already in an error state.

Persist a TracedError payload with full diagnostic metadata to error_logs. Stores all four diagnostic answers: where (file, functionName, guid), what (message, context), known failures (recovery, failureModes), and who triggered (calledBy, calls).

API route that broadcasts a hot news email to all users who have opted in to the newsFeed email preference. Enforces daily global and per-address rate limits, logs audit events, and tracks email stats.
Rate-limiting constants  caps total daily emails at 30 globally and 5 per individual address to prevent abuse and protect Graph API quotas.
Type definition for the incoming request body  content of the hot news, plus who triggered the update.
Type definition for an entry in the email_daily_stats.emailsSent array  tracks each sent email for rate-limiting and audit.
Returns today's date as an ISO date string (YYYY-MM-DD) for keying the email_daily_stats document.

POST handler  orchestrates the entire hot news email broadcast: validates input, logs audit event, checks rate limits, queries opted-in users, sends emails (including to verified secondary addresses), updates daily stats, and logs a summary audit event.
Builds the HTML email body for hot news notifications, converting newline-separated content into styled HTML paragraphs with Prix Six branding.

API route that sends a confirmation email when a user links a Google or Apple sign-in provider to their account. Sends to primary email and secondary email (if verified). Fire-and-forget from the client.
Map provider IDs to human-readable names for the email body.
POST handler  validates required fields, builds a branded confirmation email, and sends to primary (and optionally secondary) email addresses.

API route that sends race results emails to all users who have opted in (or not opted out) of results notifications. Each email is personalised with the user's prediction, score, and current standings.
Helper to obtain the Firestore db instance, wrapping getFirebaseAdmin for backwards compatibility.
Type definition for the incoming request body  identifies the race, its official result, per-team scores, and current season standings.

POST handler  queries all users who have not opted out of results notifications, builds a personalised results email for each (showing their prediction, score, race scores table, and season standings), sends via Graph API, and records delivery in email-tracking.

Builds the full HTML email body for race results, including the user's score hero section, official result table, user prediction, race scores table (sorted by points, user highlighted), and season standings table (user highlighted).

API route that sends a verification email for a user's secondary email address. Validates that the secondary email matches the user record, generates a CSPRNG token, stores it in Firestore with a 2-hour expiry, and sends a branded verification email via Graph API.
Generates a cryptographically secure 32-byte hex token for secondary email verification links.

POST handler  validates required fields (uid, secondaryEmail), checks Graph API config, verifies user exists and secondary email matches their record, generates a verification token with 2-hour expiry, stores it in Firestore, builds a branded verification email with CTA button, sends via Graph API, and logs an audit event on success.
API route that sends a primary email verification link to a user. Generates a CSPRNG token, stores it in Firestore with a 2-hour expiry, builds a branded HTML email, and sends via Graph API.
Generates a cryptographically secure 32-byte hex token for email verification links.

POST handler  validates required fields (uid, email), checks Graph API config, generates a verification token with 2-hour expiry, stores it in Firestore, builds a branded verification email with CTA button, sends via Graph API, and logs an audit event on success.
API route that sends a welcome email to a newly registered user with their team name and PIN.
POST handler  validates required fields (toEmail, teamName, pin), delegates to sendWelcomeEmail, and returns the result.
API route that accepts and stores a user's top-6 driver prediction for a specific race and team. Enforces server-side lockout rules (results exist, qualifying started).
Defines the shape of the incoming prediction submission from the user.

Main POST handler that authenticates the user, validates the prediction payload, enforces server-side lockout rules (race results exist or qualifying has started), and atomically writes the prediction and audit log to Firestore.
Authenticates the request by verifying the Firebase Auth bearer token and confirms the authenticated user matches the userId in the request body (prevents submitting on behalf of another user).
Validates that all required fields are present and that the predictions array contains exactly 6 driver IDs.

Server-side lockout enforcement: checks if race results already exist in Firestore and if qualifying has started based on Firestore race_schedule (trusted source). Uses getRaceByName() from race-schedule-server.ts instead of hardcoded RaceSchedule. Security fix: GEMINI-AUDIT-052.
Atomically writes the prediction document to the user's predictions subcollection (using merge to allow updates) and creates an audit log entry, committed as a single batch.
Top-level error handler that catches any unhandled exception during prediction submission, logs it with a correlation ID, and returns a 500 response.
Public GET endpoint that returns 50 shuffled F1-themed team name suggestions, filtered against existing team names (both primary and secondary) in Firestore. the signup page is public.
GET handler that fetches all existing team names from Firestore and returns 50 filtered, shuffled suggestions from the curated pool. so the client can fall back gracefully.

API route for adding, updating, or removing a user's secondary (communications) email address. Validates format, prevents duplicate/same-as-primary usage, resets verification status on change, and logs all changes to audit_logs.
Regex for basic email format validation  ensures the input looks like a valid email before database operations.

POST handler that orchestrates secondary email management: validates uid, handles removal (null/empty), validates email format, checks for same-as-primary and in-use conflicts, updates Firestore, and logs audit events.
Validate that uid is present in the request.
Verify the user exists in Firestore before attempting any updates.
Handle removal of secondary email  deletes both secondaryEmail and secondaryEmailVerified fields from the user document, logs removal to audit_logs.
Validate email format using regex, check secondary email is not the same as the primary email, and check it is not already in use as another user's primary email.
Persist the new secondary email (normalised to lowercase) and reset verification status to false, then log the change to audit_logs.
Top-level error handler  catches any unhandled exceptions, logs to error_logs, and returns a safe 500 response with correlation ID.
API route for verifying a user's primary email address via a token-based verification link. Validates the token, marks email as verified in both Firestore and Firebase Auth, and logs an audit event.

POST handler that validates an email verification token (constant-time comparison), checks expiry and re-use, updates both Firestore and Firebase Auth verified status, marks the token as used, and writes an audit log.
Validate that both required fields (token and uid) are present in the request.
Retrieve the verification token document and perform security checks: existence, constant-time token comparison (prevents timing attacks), re-use check, and expiry check.
Mark the user's email as verified in Firestore users collection.
Also mark as verified in Firebase Auth for consistency (Golden Rule #3). Auth failure is non-fatal  Firestore was already updated.
Mark the verification token as used to prevent re-use, and write an audit log entry.
Top-level error handler  catches any unhandled exceptions, logs to error_logs, and returns a safe 500 response with correlation ID.

API route for verifying a user's secondary (communications) email address via a token-based verification link. Similar to primary email verification but operates on the secondary_email_verification_tokens collection and does NOT update Firebase Auth.

POST handler that validates a secondary email verification token (constant-time comparison), checks expiry and re-use, verifies the secondary email has not changed since the token was issued, updates Firestore verified status, marks the token as used, and writes an audit log.
Validate that both required fields (token and uid) are present in the request.
Retrieve the secondary email verification token document and perform security checks: existence, constant-time token comparison (prevents timing attacks), re-use check, and expiry check.
Verify the user still exists and their secondary email has not changed since the verification token was issued. Prevents verifying a stale email address.
Mark the user's secondary email as verified in Firestore. NOTE: Does NOT update Firebase Auth  secondary email is for communications only, not login.
Mark the verification token as used to prevent re-use, and write an audit log entry.
Top-level error handler  catches any unhandled exceptions, logs to error_logs, and returns a safe 500 response with correlation ID.

HTTPS-to-HTTP proxy for the WhatsApp worker running on Azure Container Instances. Bridges the browser (HTTPS-only) to the internal HTTP-only WhatsApp worker, with admin auth, endpoint whitelisting, and HMAC request signing.
Internal URL constant for the WhatsApp worker  HTTP-only, not exposed to browsers. Traffic flows: Browser -> this proxy (HTTPS) -> worker (HTTP).
Generate HMAC SHA-256 signature for outgoing worker requests so the worker can verify requests originate from this trusted proxy.

GET handler  proxies read-only requests to the WhatsApp worker. Verifies admin auth, whitelists allowed endpoints (health, status, qr), signs the request, and returns the worker's response. QR endpoint returns plain text; others return JSON.
Verify the caller has a valid Firebase Auth token and is an admin user. Two-step check: token verification then Firestore isAdmin lookup.
Extract and validate the endpoint query parameter against a whitelist of allowed GET endpoints. Prevents arbitrary endpoint access on the worker.
Forward the validated GET request to the WhatsApp worker with HMAC signature. Handles QR endpoint as plain text, all others as JSON.
Catch-all error handler for GET requests  logs to console and returns a generic proxy error.
POST handler  proxies write requests to the WhatsApp worker. Verifies admin auth, whitelists allowed POST endpoints (ping, trigger-test), signs the request, and returns the worker's JSON response.
Verify the caller has a valid Firebase Auth token and is an admin user. Same two-step check as GET handler.
Extract and validate the endpoint query parameter against a whitelist of allowed POST endpoints. Prevents arbitrary write operations on the worker.
Forward the validated POST request to the WhatsApp worker with HMAC signature and return the JSON response.
Catch-all error handler for POST requests  logs to console and returns a generic proxy error.
Import statement for BackupHealthDashboard component in the admin page. Lazy-loaded by Next.js when the admin route is visited.
Root module for BackupHealthDashboard.tsx. Admin-only React component that subscribes to backup_status/latest in real-time and renders three cards: Backup Status, Immutability Lock, Smoke Test.

BackupStatus TypeScript interface mirroring the Firestore document shape written by Cloud Functions. All fields optional to handle partial population and first-run state. Includes lastBackupSizeBytes for backup size display.
TimestampDisplay component: renders Firestore Timestamps as relative time ('3 hours ago') with absolute ISO timestamp on hover tooltip. Falls back to 'Never' when no timestamp exists.
CopyButton component: one-click clipboard copy for correlation IDs. Shows green check for 2 seconds as visual confirmation. Used by ops to paste IDs into Cloud Logging search.
StatusBadge component: renders colour-coded badge for SUCCESS (green), FAILED (red), or No data (outline). Used in Backup Status and Smoke Test card headers.
Trigger a manual backup via the manualBackup callable Cloud Function.
Trigger a manual smoke test via the manualSmokeTest callable Cloud Function. Same error handling pattern as handleBackupNow. and the dashboard updates in real-time.
formatBytes utility: converts a byte count to a human-readable string (e.g. '14.2 MB'). Used by the Backup Status card to display lastBackupSizeBytes.

BackupHealthDashboard main component. Handles four states: loading (skeleton cards), error (PX-7001 alert), first-run (info alert), and normal (three-column card grid). Subscribes to backup_status/latest via useDoc.
Memoized DocumentReference for backup_status/latest. Returns null if Firestore isn't ready or user isn't admin, preventing unnecessary subscriptions.
Loading state: renders 3 skeleton cards matching the three-column layout to prevent layout shift during Firestore subscription establishment.
Error state: creates PX-7001 (BACKUP_STATUS_READ_FAILED) with correlation ID and renders a destructive Alert with copyable error details. Client-side only  does not write to error_logs.

First-run state: handles the case where backup_status/latest doesn't exist yet (dailyBackup hasn't run). Shows info alert with deployment instructions. useDoc subscription remains active so it auto-updates when the doc is created.
Normal state renderer: three-column responsive grid (1 col mobile, 3 col desktop) containing Backup Status, Immutability Lock, and Smoke Test cards.

Type definition for BackupHistoryEntry interface representing a document in the backup_history Firestore collection. Each entry records one backup run with timestamp, status, path, sizeBytes, correlationId, trigger, and optional error.
Memoized Firestore query for backup_history collection ordered by timestamp descending. Gated on admin status. Feeds useCollection hook for real-time backup history table.

handleBackfill callback  triggers listBackupHistory callable Cloud Function to backfill backup_history from existing GCS backup folders. Error paths now use PX-7008 (BACKUP_BACKFILL_FAILED) with correlation ID and selectable copyable text per Golden Rule #1.
BACKUP_DASHBOARD code block BACKUP_DASHBOARD-034

PX-7xxx error code definitions for backup & recovery system. Seven codes covering status read failure (dashboard), export failures (Firestore and Auth), smoke test failure, restore failure, cleanup failure, and heartbeat absence (Dead Man's Switch).

PX-7002.recovery: Check Cloud Function logs. Verify IAM roles for Firestore export.

PX-7007.message: Backup heartbeat missing - backup may not be running

PX-7003.recovery: Check Cloud Function logs. Verify Auth Admin SDK permissions.

PX-7004.recovery: Check lastBackupPath exists in backup_status/latest. Verify IAM roles.

PX-8001.recovery: Check login_attempts collection permissions. Non-blocking -- login still succeeds.

PX-8003.message: Failed to write login attempt to database
PX-8003.recovery: Check Firestore connectivity. Login continues even if logging fails.

PX-8004.recovery: Check attack-detection.ts. Login continues even if detection fails.

PX-9001.recovery: Check server logs with the correlation ID for root cause.

PX-9002.message: Network error - please check your connection
PX-9002.recovery: Check internet connection. Retry after a moment.

guids.description: Firebase Admin SDK initialisation at cold-start. Required before any getFirestore()/getAuth() call. Runs once per Cloud Function instance lifecycle.
Centralised configuration constants: project IDs, bucket name, region, status collection/doc path. Single point of change if the project is forked or renamed.
Generates unique correlation IDs (prefix_timestamp36_random6) for end-to-end tracing across Cloud Functions, Firestore status doc, GCS metadata, and admin dashboard.
Generates date-based GCS folder names (YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM-DD-SUNDAY). Sunday suffix is cosmetic only  retention is identical for all days.

Merges partial status fields into backup_status/latest Firestore doc using set(merge:true). Allows dailyBackup and runRecoveryTest to independently update their own fields without clobbering each other.
BACKUP_FUNCTIONS code block BACKUP_FUNCTIONS-009

dailyBackup scheduled Cloud Function (02:00 UTC daily). Orchestrates Firestore managed export, Auth JSON pagination export, status write, and BACKUP_HEARTBEAT structured log emission. Heartbeat emitted on both success and failure to prevent Dead Man's Switch double-alerting.

Firestore managed export via FirestoreAdminClient.exportDocuments() (v1 admin API). The regular Firestore data client does NOT have exportDocuments() or databasePath()  must use the admin client from @google-cloud/firestore v1 namespace.

Auth user export via Admin SDK listUsers() pagination (1000/page). Serialises user metadata (uid, email, displayName, providers, customClaims) to JSON in GCS. Does NOT include password hashes  Firebase Auth does not expose them.

Writes SUCCESS status to backup_status/latest after both Firestore and Auth exports complete. Explicitly nulls lastBackupError to clear any previous failure state. Now also writes lastBackupSizeBytes from BACKUP_FUNCTIONS-018.
Emits BACKUP_HEARTBEAT structured JSON log on the success path. This log feeds the log-based metric backup_heartbeat_count, which the Dead Man's Switch MQL alert monitors for absence >25 hours.

Error handler for dailyBackup. Writes FAILED status to backup_status/latest, emits BACKUP_HEARTBEAT with severity:ERROR (to prevent DMS double-alert), then re-throws so Cloud Functions marks the invocation as failed.
BACKUP_FUNCTIONS code block BACKUP_FUNCTIONS-016

Call performBackup and return structured success/failure response. On failure, include correlationId and errorCode (PX-7002) so the frontend can display a Golden Rule #1 compliant error with copyable details. The correlationId is extracted from the error object where performBackup attaches it before re-throwing.
Calculates total backup size by listing all GCS objects under the backup folder prefix and summing their sizes. Result stored in lastBackupSizeBytes for admin dashboard display.

runRecoveryTest scheduled Cloud Function (04:00 UTC Sundays). Imports the latest backup into a disposable recovery project, verifies critical documents exist, cleans up, and writes smoke test result to status doc.
Reads lastBackupPath from backup_status/latest. Guards against the case where no backup has ever run  fails loudly so ops investigates rather than silently skipping the smoke test.

Imports the Firestore export into the recovery project via FirestoreAdminClient.importDocuments() (v1 admin API). Must use the admin client, not the data client. Recovery project is ephemeral and cleaned up after verification.

Smoke test verification using the regular Firestore data client (not admin client  data reads use collection/doc/get). Checks system_status/heartbeat exists AND users collection has at least one document. Both failing = backup is empty or corrupt.

Post-verification cleanup: deletes all data in the recovery project Firestore. Non-fatal  cleanup failure is logged but does not fail the smoke test because the primary goal (verification) has already succeeded.
Writes SUCCESS smoke test status to backup_status/latest and emits SMOKE_TEST_COMPLETE structured log with verification results.
Error handler for runRecoveryTest. Writes FAILED status to backup_status/latest with the error message, then re-throws.
deleteAllCollections: enumerates all top-level collections in recovery Firestore and batch-deletes every document. Errors are caught and logged (non-fatal by design  next import overwrites anyway).
deleteCollection: batch-deletes all documents in a single collection using batches of 500 (Firestore maximum). Loops until collection is empty. Does not recurse into subcollections.
BACKUP_FUNCTIONS code block BACKUP_FUNCTIONS-040
Writes a SUCCESS history entry to backup_history collection after a successful backup, recording timestamp, status, path, sizeBytes, correlationId, and trigger type.
Writes a FAILED history entry to backup_history collection when a backup fails, recording timestamp, status, correlationId, trigger, and error message for audit trail.

listBackupHistory callable Cloud Function. Admin-only. Backfills backup_history collection from existing GCS backup folder prefixes. Lists all top-level prefixes in gs://prix6-backups/, sums file sizes per prefix, writes to backup_history if not already present, returns full list. On failure returns PX-7008 with correlationId and writes failure record to backup_history.
Lists all top-level folder prefixes in the backup GCS bucket using delimiter-based listing. Each prefix represents one backup run.
Process a single GCS prefix: check if already backfilled, sum file sizes with paginated listing, parse timestamp, and write the history entry. Returns the entry object.

Process prefixes in parallel batches of 10 to stay well within the 540s Cloud Functions timeout. A deadline guard ensures we return a partial result instead of being killed by Cloud Run mid-flight. results if deadline approached. Caller can re-invoke to pick up remaining prefixes.
Write smoke test history entry so admins can see all past smoke test runs alongside backups in the history table.
Write smoke test failure history entry for audit trail.
Main application sidebar component providing navigation links, admin panel access,
Static menu item configuration defining all navigation routes available to regular users.
Exported sidebar component that renders the full navigation sidebar including header
Handles user logout by first setting the Firestore presence document to offline,

Full-screen cinematic intro animation for the About page. Plays a 24-second F1-themed sequence through four phases: Grid Entry (version display), Telemetry (live stats), Module Tour (feature showcase), and Finish (chequered flag + logo). First-time visitors see this automatically; returning visitors can replay it.
Props interface for CinematicIntro. Receives live data (totalTeams, onlineUsers) and a completion callback.
F1 brand red colour constant used throughout the intro for visual consistency.
Timing configuration for the four animation phases. Each phase has a start and end time in milliseconds, controlling the overall 24-second animation timeline.
Static data for the module tour phase (Phase 3). Each entry has a Lucide icon, display name, and short description representing a key app feature.
Animated number counter that eases from 0 to a target value over a specified duration. Used in the telemetry phase to display live stats with a dramatic count-up effect.
Drives the count-up animation using setInterval at ~60fps. Applies a cubic ease-out curve for a decelerating effect.
Text component that periodically applies a brief RGB-shift glitch effect, creating a cyberpunk/HUD aesthetic for the version number display.
Renders a CSS perspective grid with horizontal and vertical lines, creating a retro F1 starting grid / Tron-like visual. Horizontal lines animate downward when isMoving is true.
Heads-Up Display overlay with vignette darkening, scan lines, corner brackets, and status readouts. Creates an immersive cockpit/telemetry screen aesthetic.
Animated chequered flag pattern that sweeps across the screen from left to right during the finish phase, signalling the end of the intro sequence.
SVG logo for "PRIX SIX" with animated path drawing. Each letter (P, R, I, X) is drawn sequentially using Framer Motion's pathLength animation, followed by a fade-in "SIX" text element.

Main CinematicIntro component. Orchestrates the 4-phase animation sequence using timed state transitions. Renders a full-screen black overlay with phase-specific content, a skip button, and a progress bar.
Skip handler allowing users to bypass the intro at any point. Sets phase to 'done' and immediately calls onComplete.
Master timeline orchestrator. Schedules all phase transitions, module cycling, flag display, and completion using setTimeout calls based on PHASE_TIMINGS. All timers are cleaned up on unmount.

Main render: full-screen fixed overlay with AnimatePresence managing phase transitions. Each phase renders its own motion.div with entry/exit animations. Skip button and progress bar are always visible.

Dismissable banner that prompts PIN-only users to link a Google or Apple account. Similar pattern to EmailVerificationBanner but with blue/purple theme. Shows only when the user's providerData contains only 'password'. Auto-hides on successful link. Dismissable for the current session.

Main exported component. Renders only for PIN-only users (no OAuth provider linked). Provides Link Google and Link Apple buttons with loading and success states. the user's providers list, causing this banner to auto-hide.
Link Google account to the current user.
Link Apple account to the current user.
Client-side dashboard component providing real-time countdown to qualifying,
Determines deadline urgency level based on time remaining until qualifying.
TypeScript interface for the countdown time breakdown (days/hours/minutes/seconds).
Pure function to compute remaining time from now until targetDate.
Main client dashboard component  renders countdown timer, deadline warnings,
Memoised prediction document ID constructed from user ID and race ID.
Memoised Firestore document reference for the user's prediction for this race.
Recurring 1-second timer that recalculates the countdown to qualifying.
Dismissable banner component that prompts unverified users to verify their email address.
Main exported component that renders the email verification banner with send/refresh
Triggers the verification email send flow with loading state and result feedback.
Refreshes the email verification status by reloading the Firebase Auth user.
SVG icon components for Google and Apple sign-in buttons. Match lucide-react API (className, size props) for consistent use with Button components.
Google "G" logo SVG matching the official brand colour palette.
Apple logo SVG in currentColor for theme compatibility.

PredictionEditor component: the core prediction interface where users select, reorder, and submit their top-6 driver predictions for a race. Also provides AI-powered analysis with configurable weights, countdown timer, apply-to-all-teams option, and a change log.
Configuration array defining the 11 AI analysis facets (9 data-driven + 2 personality-driven). Each facet has a key matching AnalysisWeights, a display label, icon emoji, and description.
Default weight values for each AI analysis facet. Data facets default to 7, personality facets to 5.
Maximum total weight budget (11 facets x 7 = 77). Enforces a constraint so users must trade off emphasis between facets.
Props interface for PredictionEditor. Receives driver list, lock state, initial predictions, race metadata, team info, and circuit name.
Main PredictionEditor component. Manages prediction grid state, countdown timer, submission flow, AI analysis, and change history.
Load user's saved AI analysis weights from Firestore on mount. Overrides DEFAULT_WEIGHTS if the user has previously customised and saved their preferences.
Memoised calculation of the sum of all current weight values, used for budget enforcement and display.
Countdown timer that updates every second, showing time remaining until qualifying (the prediction deadline). Displays days/hours/minutes/seconds format and shows "CLOSED" when past.
Computed list of drivers not yet selected in the prediction grid, sorted alphabetically. Powers the "Available Drivers" panel.
Appends a change description to the history log (max 5 entries). Optionally includes a timestamp for significant actions like submissions.
Adds a driver to the first empty slot in the prediction grid. No-op if the grid is locked.
Removes a driver from a specific position in the prediction grid, setting that slot to null. No-op if the grid is locked.
Swaps a driver with the adjacent slot (up or down) to reorder predictions. No-op if locked or at grid boundary.
Submits the prediction to the server via /api/submit-prediction. Supports multi-team submission when "Apply to All" is checked. Validates grid completeness and user authentication before sending.
Handles weight slider changes with budget enforcement. Caps the new value if it would exceed MAX_TOTAL_WEIGHT.
Resets all analysis weights back to DEFAULT_WEIGHTS values.
Persists the current AI analysis weights to the user's Firestore document. Fire-and-forget: failure is logged but not shown to the user.

Requests AI-powered race analysis from /api/ai/analysis with the current predictions and weights. Validates grid completeness first. Handles errors with correlation IDs and user-copyable error toasts per Golden Rule #1.

Main render: two-column layout with prediction grid card (left/top) and sidebar (right/bottom) containing available drivers, change log, and AI analysis panel. Full-width AI result card spans below both columns when analysis is active.

Card component that prompts PIN-only users to link a Google or Apple account for improved security. Uses the AccountLinker facade to perform the upgrade. Displays idle, loading, success, and error states. via Firebase Auth. On success, onAuthStateChanged syncs providers to Firestore.

Main exported component. Shows upgrade prompt for PIN-only users, with Google and Apple link buttons. Renders a success confirmation after linking. happens automatically via onAuthStateChanged in the background.
Handle the upgrade action for a given provider.
Developer-facing version history component that displays a timeline of git commits
